relationships.notes: Agrippa II convenes with Bernice and the Roman governor Festus to hear Paul’s testimony, allowing the apostle to narrate his persecution of the church, Damascus road encounter, and commission to preach the risen Jesus.

Although Agrippa never meets Jesus, Paul presses him to believe the prophets by recounting how Jesus fulfilled Scripture through death and resurrection, positioning Agrippa as a royal evaluator of the gospel message.

traits.identity_and_context: Appears as King Agrippa, visiting Caesarea with Bernice during the governorship of Festus, and consulted about Paul’s case.
traits.knowledge_of_jewish_matters: Recognized by Paul as knowledgeable about Jewish customs and controversies, making him an appropriate hearer for Paul’s defense.
traits.hearing_of_paul: Listens to Paul’s detailed account of his background, persecution of Christians, and encounter with the risen Jesus on the Damascus road.
traits.reaction_to_message: Responds skeptically or ambivalently to Paul’s appeal, with the famous remark about whether Paul would persuade him to become a Christian in such a short time.
traits.assessment_of_paul: Concludes with Festus that Paul has done nothing deserving death or imprisonment and could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar.
traits.narrative_function: Serves as a royal audience for Paul’s testimony, highlighting both the plausibility of Paul’s case and the ongoing distance between the movement and certain elite hearers.
